contextId.information: Paul uses this question to emphasize he was sure about his decision to visit the Corinthians. The expected answer to the question is no. AT: "I was not hesitating" or "I was confident in my decision" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

Paul uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that neither he nor they would benefit if his coming to them would cause them pain. AT: "If I caused you pain, the only ones who could cheer me up would be the very ones whom I had hurt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: If I caused you pain, who could cheer me up but the very one who was hurt by me?

contextId.information: Paul uses this question to emphasize that they are not bragging about themselves. AT: "We are not beginning to praise ourselves again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Are we beginning to praise ourselves again?

contextId.information: Paul says this to express that the Corinthians already know about Paul and Timothy's good reputation. The question prompts a negative answer. AT: "We certainly do not need letters of recommendation to you or from you, like some people do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: We do not need letters of recommendation to you or from you, like some people, do we?

contextId.information: Paul uses this question to emphasize that "the service that the Spirit does" must be more glorious than "the service that produced" because it leads to life. AT: "So the service that the Spirit does must be even more glorious" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: How much more glorious will be the service that the Spirit does?

contextId.information: This is a rhetorical question that anticipates a negative answer. AT: "A believer shares nothing in common with an unbeliever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Or what share does a believer have together with an unbeliever?

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) this is a command or 2) this is a statement, "You are looking only at what you can see with your eyes." Some think this is a rhetorical question which may also be written as a statement. AT: "Are you looking at what is clearly in front of you?" or "You seem unable to see what is clearly in front of you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Look at what is clearly in front of you

contextId.information: Paul is beginning to claim that he treated the Corinthians well. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement, if necessary. AT: "I think we agree that I did not sin by humbling myself so you might be exalted" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Did I sin by humbling myself so you might be exalted?

contextId.information: Paul uses this question to express his anger when a fellow believer is caused to sin. Here his anger is spoken of as a burning inside him. This rhetorical question can be translated as  statement. AT: "Whenever anyone causes a brother to sin, I am angry." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Who has been caused to stumble, and I do not burn?

contextId.information: Paul is emphasizing that the Corinthians are wrong to accuse him of wanting to do them harm. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "I treated you the same way I treated all the other churches, except that ... you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: how were you less important than the rest of the churches, except that ... you?

contextId.information: This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "If I love you so much, you should not love me so little." or "If ... much, you should love me more than you do." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: If I love you more, am I to be loved less?

contextId.information: Both Paul and the Corinthians know the answer is no. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "Titus did not take advantage of you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Did Titus take advantage of you?

contextId.information: Paul speaks of living as if it were walking on a road. Both Paul and the Corinthians know the answer to the question is yes. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "We all have the same attitude and live alike." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Did we not walk in the same way?

contextId.information: Paul is asking a rhetorical question, AT: "It is wrong for you to think that all of this time we have been defending ourselves to you." Some translate this as a statement. AT: "You have been thinking all this time that we have been defending ourselves to you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you think all of this time we have been defending ourselves to you?
